snippet: Dozens of Shabab defectors live in a halfway house in Baidoa, Somalia, where they are learning new skills but live in fear of their old comrades.
abstract: Dozens of defectors from the Shabab militant group have taken refuge at a halfway house in Baidoa, Somalia, where they live in fear of reprisal from their former comrades; testimony from men paints picture of Shabab as an unraveling organization, lacking a charismatic leader and regularly losing troops to desertion, but one that nonetheless remains dangerous.

byline.original: By ISMA'IL KUSHKUSH and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
byline.contributor: Isma’il Kushkush reported from Baidoa, Somalia, and Jeffrey Gettleman from Nairobi, Kenya.

lead_paragraph: Dozens of Shabab defectors live in a halfway house in Baidoa, Somalia, where they are learning new skills but live in fear of their old comrades.

headline.main: As Power of Terror Group Declines, Once-Feared Fighters Defect
headline.print_headline: As Power of Terror Group Declines, Once Feared Fighters Defect
